Q:

How to use a Non-Existing property in a T4 template

I have a template that I use to generate a bunch of code files.  I have a property that represents the file name, and I need to use it in the code template.  But, the property doesn't exist.  So, I tried doing this:
<#=fileName#>

But, that didn't work.  I also tried:
<#=fileName#>

But, that didn't work either.

A:

You can't use a property name that doesn't exist in the generated code file. You need to use a variable, and use the same name as the property you're referencing.
In your file, you would do something like this:
<#=File.ReadAllText(Path.Combine(projectpath, "MyTemplate.cshtml")) #>

Then, in your template, you would reference it like this:
<#=fileName#>

STL is a collection of template classes and functions that provide a standard interface for algorithms and data structures.

STL is a set of classes and algorithms that provide a standard interface for classes that manipulate and work with geometrically-defined objects such as points, lines, and polygons.

This interface allows you to treat objects in the STL as if they were homogeneous data types. This interface enables you to express algorithms and data structures as if they were functions, and it allows you to treat objects as arguments to those functions.

The STL uses C++'s Standard Template Library (STL) classes and algorithms to perform basic geometric computations.

All the Arts, All the Time

Theater review: Michael Nyman's 'The Draughtsman's Contract'

May 16, 2009 | 10:12
pm

Michael Nyman’s “The Draughtsman’s Contract” is the latest of his lush, evocative chamber works to come to Broadway. Even before the show opens, the word "syllabus" may come to mind: The libretto is a kind of sketch, a loosely structured, unfinished work that provides a soundtrack for the show and the life of the characters it depicts.

But “The Draughtsman’s Contract” is not a mere sketch; it is the work of a mature artist who, in his long career, has demonstrated his mastery of an expansive range of compositional techniques, from minimalism to serialism to aleatoric music. The opera, which won the British composer a MacArthur “genius” fellowship in 2003, consists of five scenes that explore different aspects of human experience.

The first scene, “The Blue Room,” is a musical setting of a cry for help that is the climax of a play by Anton Chekhov. The music is sweeping, as if to suggest the emotions of Chekhov’s characters; the music is fragmented and dissonant, as if to suggest the characters’ fragmented, disjointed, inner lives. The duet between a woman and her lover is a gorgeous, moving melody.

The second scene, “The Dining Room,” is a musical setting of a speech by the political philosopher John Stuart Mill. The speech deals with the topic of the social contract, which Mill believed was the basis of morality. The music is lyrical and evocative, but it is also tender, as if to suggest the fragility of the human soul.

The final scene, “The Study,” is a musical setting of an exchange between the main characters in the play “The Seagull.” The setting is dramatic, and the music is harmonically and melodically complex, as if to suggest the characters’ complicated inner lives.

The solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC), which is a fuel cell having a small size, a long lifetime, and a high reliability, is a promising candidate for replacing conventional fossil fuel-based power generation systems. The solid oxide fuel cell, whose fuel is oxygen (O2) gas, has a relatively high energy conversion efficiency, an extremely high durability, and a fast response to a load change.
The solid oxide fuel cell is advantageous in that it is light and compact and can be operated at lower temperatures than other fuel cells. In addition, as compared to a metallic fuel cell, the solid oxide fuel cell has a longer lifetime, a higher operation efficiency, and a lower manufacturing cost.

Q:

Getting an error while using the C++11 standard library in Xcode

I am using Xcode 4.6.3 with C++11 standard library. I need to include some header files (for example, std::string) and I get the following error:

'<CxxLanguageStandard>': use of undeclared identifier 'std'

What should I do?

A:

The compiler must be told what language you want to compile. To do this you need to place the -std=c++11 flags in your compiler options or in your project settings.

A:

When you are compiling C++ code with GCC (or Clang), you will find out that you must add -std=c++11 flag in order to compile the code with the correct C++11 standard library.
In Xcode, you need to set the "C++ Language Dialect" under the "Build Settings" tab.

All-optical switching of a coherent light pulse without an external optical modulator.
We report all-optical switching of a coherent light pulse without an external optical modulator. The switching is accomplished by multiple reflections in a microring resonator with a finite interaction length. The switching is accomplished by the interference of the reflected light pulses generated by a cascaded Mach-Zehnder interferometer. The reflected pulse is shifted in phase by π and is amplified by a self-phase modulation effect. We experimentally demonstrate switching of a light pulse whose input power is below the threshold of the Kerr nonlinearity. This scheme is simpler than any previous optical switching techniques and can be easily implemented in a simple photonic chip.Prof. Dr. Mohammadreza Sajjadi, who had a very busy year, 2014 at the University of Maryland, College Park, is the recipient of the prestigious "Outstanding Alumni Award" from the Alumni Association

Perfect information can mean a lot of things, and it's not as simple as you might think.
Most games where the players have complete knowledge of the state of the game, that is, they know every empty spot in the game board, are not considered "perfect information" games. 
"Perfect information" usually refers to a game where the players know all the "full" information about the state of the game, and not just what the next player turns are.
So, a game with perfect information is one in which the players know the entire state of the game and not just the next player turns.

user_prompt: Write me a high quality testing framework in Cypress that utilizes Docker, and also uses Cypress's ability to capture screenshots and save them.
assistant_prompt:
est -a -r '{ "name": "www.example.com" }' | xargs -n 1 docker run -d --name=www.example.com -p 80:80 -v /tmp/screenshots:/var/cache/docker/images/www.example.com -d example/screenshot-example.com/

container_names=$(docker ps -a | grep -v 'no name' | awk -F ',' '{print $1}')

if [[ "${container_names}" != "www.example.com" ]]; then
    docker build -t example/screenshot-example.com .
    docker rm -f www.example.com
    docker run --rm -v /var/cache/docker/images/www.example.com:/var/lib/docker/containers/www.example.com example/screenshot-example.com
fi

Note that the output of the docker ps -a | grep -v 'no name' | awk -F ',' '{print $1}' command is the name of the container. You need to be able to tell which one it is.
The condition checks if the container name is not "www.example.com". If it is, then docker rm -f is run to remove the container and the second command, docker run --rm -v /var/cache/docker/images/www.example.com:/var/lib/docker/containers/www.example.com example/screenshot-example.com, runs the container.

In this film, we walk through some of the challenges LLM's face and then we'll examine the difference between high-level and low-level calculations.

Finally, we'll discuss the strengths and weaknesses of these different methods of calculation.

_The Challenge of Calculating a Collatz Sequence_

Imagine that you are given the following sequence of numbers:

1101001

110100101

110100101001

11010010100101

11010010100101001

1101001010010100101

1101001010010100101001

110100101001010010100101

110100101001010010100101001

11010010100101001010010100101

This is a sequence of numbers that is not yet a Collatz sequence. In order to generate the Collatz sequence, we would start at 1 and then repeatedly multiply the number by 3, and then ask if the number is greater than 1. If it is, the number is multiplied by 2 and the process continues. Eventually, the number will be 1 and the sequence will stop.

Here is a summary of the process:

Step 1 | Multiply the number by 3 and find its digit.  
---|---  
Step 2 | If the number is greater than 1, multiply the number by 2 and find its digit.  
Step 3 | If the number is greater than 1, the process continues until it reaches 1.  
Step 4 | Write out the sequence of numbers.

The problem with this sequence is that, at the end, the numbers have an infinite sequence of digits. For example, if we start at 1, we will repeat the sequence indefinitely:

1, 3, 9, 27, 81, 243, 729, 2187, 7049, 19627, 49209, 145943, 403009, 1186559, 3533927, 10979863, 31704081, 103630921, 344574459, 1365310807, 4249336289, 161259329

The world's first computer was not invented until 1947 when, at the University of Pennsylvania, Dr. J. Eckert and Mauchly's machine was not the world's first but the first to be in any way commercially successful. In 1949, Eckert and Mauchly started a company, Computing-Tabulating-Recording Company (CTR), to market their E-machine.
A few years later, Dr. John Hench and a team of engineers at the University of Pennsylvania built the UNIVAC, the first commercially successful electronic computer. The UNIVAC was the first computer designed primarily to be a business computer.
The UNIVAC was built by placing a set of vacuum tubes in a large cabinet, each tube representing a binary digit of the computer. The basic architecture of the UNIVAC was borrowed from E-machine. In 1949, the UNIVAC was installed at the Philadelphia Navy Yard. In 1951, the first UNIVAC was shipped to the National Bureau of Standards in Washington, D.C.
In 1951, the first commercial computer, the IBM 650 was developed by Eckert and Mauchly's former students, Presper Weinberger and John W. Backus at the University of Pennsylvania. The IBM 650 could perform basic mathematical functions such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. The IBM 650 was much smaller than the UNIVAC, weighing less than three tons. It was the first commercial computer that was smaller than a room.
The IBM 650 was designed to be used for business applications. In 1954, IBM developed the first business computer, the IBM 701. The IBM 701 was a commercial success.

Could you provide a brief summary of the book "Fooled by Randomness", by Nassim Nicholas Taleb? Please provide a few paragraphs with the summary and the main points discussed in the book. 
How well the book was accepted and was there any negative or positive critic of the work presented there?
assistant_prompt:
A:

The book is about the limits of statistics, and the importance of understanding the assumptions underlying an experiment. 
Taleb's book has come under more scrutiny over the past few years, as people have begun to understand how crucial those assumptions are to the validity of randomized controlled trials. 
Taleb argues that the current state of medicine is one of trial and error, where we try things and see what works. We don't know what works, and we don't know whether it will work in the future. We just know what our current knowledge is. 
He argues that the best way to allocate resources is by using methods that have been proven to work in the past. Randomized trials are valuable because they can be done cheaply, and because they are the only way we can prove that a treatment works.
However, Taleb argues that the current state of medicine is an example of the adage, "When the facts change, I change my mind. What do you do, sir?" He argues that the evidence we have today may not hold true in the future. 
He says that the field of medicine looks for a magic bullet, a drug that will be the cure-all. But because we are no better in understanding the underlying mechanisms of disease than we were a generation ago, we may be on the verge of a paradigm shift, where the treatments we currently use will only incur more side-effects. 
Taleb's book is a well-written, entertaining read, and it's worth being aware of the issues he raises. The book is available for free in PDF on his website.

Q:

How to convert the result of a query to a list

Is there a way to convert the result of a query to a list?
For example, if I have a query like this:
SELECT * FROM my_table where my_field = "xxx";

How can I fetch the rows in a list format?

A:

Assuming you are using a Sqlite3 database, you can use .fetchall() to get all the rows.
Assuming you have a sqlite3 database named "mydb" with your table "my_table":
my_list = []

with mydb.cursor() as cursor:
    cursor.execute("SELECT * FROM my_table where my_field = 'xxx'")
    my_list.extend(cursor.fetchall())

my_list

This will return a list of all the rows from your table, which is probably what you want.
You can also use it like this:
cursor.execute("SELECT * FROM my_table where my_field = 'xxx'")
my_rows = cursor.fetchall()

my_rows will be a list of all the rows returned from your query.

The following is an excerpt from the Wikipedia article on two factor authentication:

Two-factor authentication (2FA) is a procedure that requires the
  user to provide more than one factor to prove their identity and to
  access a service.
Two-factor authentication using a physical device is a form of
  physical access control. In this method, a user is required to have
  access to a physical token or key, which they use to log into the
  service.
Two-factor authentication using a password is a method of access
  control whereby the user may need to enter a password to be
  authenticated. This is sometimes called a second-factor authentication
  system.
Two-factor authentication using a biometric is a form of
  two-factor authentication that uses a biometric identifier, such as
  a fingerprint or retina scan, to verify the identity of a user.

An example of a 2nd factor would be a card that has your name on it.  If I were to give you a card with my name on it and you were to hand it to me, I could check your balance without having to have your account number.  This would seem to make sense, as it would prevent someone from just taking your card and creating an account with your name on it.

Checking your online account activity

If you were to give me your account number, I could check your activity on your online account.  This is a little harder to explain.  The way this works is that you are using your second factor (the account number) to send a message to your online account.  It is then encrypted or signed with your password.  When you send this message, you are also sending your password as well.  This is all done with the 2nd factor, which makes it safe.

Checking your online account activity

This is the way most websites do 2FA.  When you log in, you are sent a link that you have to use your 2nd factor to decrypt.  This link is sent to your email

em.co.zaPsychological stress can be a problem for people. It can cause you to feel overwhelmed, angry, sad or irritable. It can also lead to nervous exhaustion and physical symptoms like headaches, stomach pains, sleeplessness and headaches.

The most common cause of stress is negative thinking. When you are thinking negative thoughts, such as ‘I’m no good at this’ or ‘I’m stupid’, it is likely that you will be stressed. You can use your mind to think positively. Begin by writing down five things that you are grateful for and then think about these things to help you feel better.

The next most common cause of stress is depression. When negative thinking and lack of self-worth are combined with a lack of motivation and a lack of hope, depression can develop.

Try to find the silver lining in every situation. This can help you to feel better and cope with stressful situations.

The third common cause of stress is having too many problems to deal with at once. People can become overwhelmed when they have to deal with too many things at once. This can be when you have to work, do your homework, go to school, help your siblings and parents, take care of your house or do other household chores.

The fourth cause of stress is overcommitment. When you are overcommitted, it is hard to say no to others. This can lead to stress. People who are overcommitted tend to feel tired, frustrated and unfulfilled.

The fifth cause of stress is having too little money. When you do not have enough money, it is difficult to meet your needs. This can lead to stress. People who are low on money have less control and they worry about where their next meal will come from.

How can you cope with stress?

First, you need to know what causes stress.
